title: We Need To Talk About The Homophobia In This Trump/Putin Street Art
text:
We Need To Talk About The Homophobia In This Trump/Putin Street Art Tenderness between two men shouldn't be alarming or mockable. By James Michael Nichols 
Protest art is nothing new. 
For years, people have used art in a multitude of mediums to express discontent with, among other things, a current political climate or the state of the world around them. 
And on Valentine‚Äôs Day, a dating app called Hater projected an image of a naked Putin fondling a pregnant Trump on the side of buildings in New York‚Äôs Williamsburg and Chelsea neighborhoods. A post shared by Hater (@lovethroughhate) on Feb 14, 2017 at 7:01pm PST 
Of course, we‚Äôve seen similar images in the past, like when this mural of the pair kissing popped up in Lithuania‚Äôs capital last May. A photo posted by @keuleruke on May 12, 2016 at 5:17am PDT 
Sure, the images may be made from artists around the globe, but they all share a common theme: they reinforce the idea that affection or romance between two men is either something to be mocked or a sign of weakness. 
And at the end of the day, this outdated belief is rooted in homophobic notions of how men should act with one another. 
The artist‚Äôs real ‚Äújoke‚Äù here, of course, lies in the fragile, toxic nature of masculinity and the idea that affection between men is so outrageous that depicting these two (very unpopular) world leaders in this way is somehow funny. 
But it‚Äôs not. And this idea that queer men are somehow weak or more effeminate than those identifying as straight ‚Äï and that this makes them mockable ‚Äï is something that LGBTQ people have always fought throughout history. Sean Gallup via Getty Images 
The questions we should be asking ourselves are: Why do we keep seeing different variations of this Trump/Putin image? What is so funny about love between men? Why is the idea that failing masculinity through male-on-male affection one that our culture reproduces over and over again? Even in art-based contexts that are supposed to be progressive? 
We all know that masculinity is fragile ‚Äï so fragile in fact that it seems to be the end-game that many Americans go to when they‚Äôre reaching for something to make fun of Trump about. 
But we need to do better. There are ways to critique our president and his alleged problematic relationship with Vladimir Putin without placing that critique in a framework that, at the end of the day, is homophobic. @cher what's wrong with this picture üòÇüòÇüòÇ pic.twitter.com/uMJQ0FhYAx ‚Äî Heather ‚ù£Ô∏èüíñ (@HJay1976) August 8, 2016 
To be fair, there is something to be said for the idea of reframing their relationship through a queer lens that empowers gayness and celebrates queer relationships. Tenderness between two men shouldn‚Äôt be alarming, even it it‚Äôs Trump and Putin. 
But I suspect that isn‚Äôt the intentions of the artists creating these works. 
We are all living in scary, surreal times. But let‚Äôs be intentional in the ways we‚Äôre dealing with that reality ‚Äï and intentional about the choices we make with our forms of resistance, no matter what medium that may be.
